bioghist.p: John Archibald Wheeler (b. 1911) is a leading figure in the development of general relativity and quantum gravity. He received his doctorate from Johns Hopkins University in 1933. He was professor of physics at Princeton University from 1938 to 1976, then professor of physics at the University of Texas at Austin. Wheeler's graduate students included Richard Feynman, Kip Thorne, and Hugh Everett. He was a pioneer in the theory of nuclear fission, along with Niels Bohr and Enrico Fermi. In 1939 he collaborated with Bohr on the liquid drop model of nuclear fission. Together with other leading physicists during World War II, Wheeler participated in the development of the atomic bomb under the Manhattan Project at Hanford, Washington. He went on to work on the development of the American hydrogen bomb under Project Matterhorn B. After concluding his Project Matterhorn work, Wheeler returned to Princeton to resume his academic career. In 1957, while working on extensions to general relativity, he introduced the word "wormhole" to describe tunnels in space-time. His work in general relativity included the theory of gravitational collapse, and in 1967 he coined the term "black hole." Wheeler was awarded the Wolf Prize in Physics in 1997. He maintained an office at Princeton until 2006.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of professional and personal papers of John Wheeler. Professional materials include: correspondence with colleagues related to articles, awards, and talks; calculations, graphs and diagrams, lecture notes and overhead transparencies; reprints and articles by Wheeler and others; dissertations and manuscripts by others, including copies of Crawford H. Greenewalt's diaries; awards and diplomas; and photographs. Personal materials include: letters to and from Wheeler's family, including a series from his mother (1935-1959); greeting cards; newspaper clippings; genealogical information on Reverend John Wheeler; a file of quotations collected by Wheeler; a memoir entitled "It from Bit"; a scrapbook kept by Wheeler; an unidentified 1911 travel diary; and family photographs. The collection also includes Wheeler's FBI file, and miscellaneous artifacts, such as drafting tools, pins, and commemorative plates.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
